etymologies: late Middle English: contraction of fantasy

definitions: sophisticated or expensive in a way that is intended to impress
(of a flower) of two or more colors

examples.text: all pelargoniums, from scented-leaf species to fancy hybrids, thrive in hot sunshine

definitions: (of an animal) bred to develop particular points of appearance
(of a drawing, painting, or sculpture) created from the imagination rather than from life

examples.text: I used to take a seat and busy myself in sketching fancy vignettes

definitions: feel a desire or liking for
have an unduly high opinion of oneself, or of one's ability in a particular area

examples.text: two lads behind the counter who fancy themselves

synonyms.text: have a high opinion of oneself

definitions: regard (a horse, team, or player) as a likely winner

examples.text: I fancy him to win the tournament
he fancied he could smell the perfume of roses
he fancied himself as an amateur psychologist

definitions: used to express surprise at something

examples.text: fancy meeting all those television actors!

definitions: a feeling of liking or attraction, typically one that is superficial or transient

examples.text: this does not mean that the law should change with every passing fancy
my research assistant is prone to flights of fancy

definitions: a thing that one supposes or imagines, typically an unfounded or tentative belief or idea; notion or whim
(in 16th and 17th century music) a composition for keyboard or strings in free or variation form.
